I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Nepal for the COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program (CARES Program), 
under the Countercyclical Support Facility COVID-19 pandemic response option (CPRO).1 
  
2.  The CARES Program will help the government in implementing its pandemic response 
plan—the National Relief Program—to respond to public health emergencies and to mitigate 
adverse economic and social impacts caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. 
The National Relief Program, approved on 29 March 2020, includes medical and health support, 
social protection for the poor and vulnerable, economic support for affected sectors, and other 
fiscal and economic measures.2 Nepal meets all the CPRO access criteria (Table 1) and the 
detailed justifications are in Appendix 4.

1. Adverse impact of  The COVID-19 pandemic has caused severe sudden disruptions to the economy. It is 
exogenous shocks   projected to lead to economic loss of $2.3 billion or 7.1% of GDP in FY2020 and 
FY2021. ADB projected 6.3% GDP growth for FY2020 before the pandemic; however, 
the official GDP growth is estimated to decline to 2.3%.  With rising health and economic 
relief measures, the FY2020 fiscal deficit is projected to widen from the pre-pandemic 
estimate of 6.4% of GDP to 8.5% of GDP. ADB estimates that the economy may lose 
about 4.7% of total employment or 997,000 jobs for FY2020–FY2021.a The IMF’s May 
2020 report on the Rapid Credit Facility projects Nepal’s GDP growth to be 1.0% in 
FY2020 and 3.5% in FY2021.b 
2. Countercyclical  On 29 March 2020, the government approved the National Relief Program, consisting 
development  of (i) health and medical support, (ii) social protection for the poor and vulnerable, and 
expenditures  (iii)  economic  support  for  affected  sectors.  The  government’s  countercyclical 
development expenditure program is estimated to cost about $1.26 billion for FY2020, 
of which: (i) $347 million for health and medical support, (ii) $359 million for social 
protection for the poor and vulnerable, and (iii) $555 million for economic support for 
affected sectors. 
3. Pre-shock record of  Nepal’s macroeconomic management has been generally sound with fast growth and 
generally sound  benign inflation. GDP growth averaged 7.3% during FY2017–FY2019. Inflation declined 
macroeconomic  steadily from a peak of 9.9% in FY2016 to 6.5% in the first 8 months of FY2020. The 
management  fiscal deficit moderated to 5.1% of GDP in FY2019, down from 6.6% in FY2018. Gross 
foreign exchange reserves were adequate at $9.5 billion at the end of FY2019, enough 
to cover 7.8 months of imports, in FY2019. With an average revenue–GDP ratio of 
23.8% from FY2017 to FY2019, the revenue mobilization, excluding foreign grants, has 
been robust.  
4. Structural reforms  As part of the pandemic response, the government has begun structural reforms to 
enhance public sector resilience to emergencies, especially in the health sector. MOHP 
developed the Health Sector Emergency Response Plan: COVID-19 Pandemic to 
develop detailed institutional mechanisms and interventions to be adopted during a 
pandemic.c The government also incorporated finance sector structural reforms to 
enable the regulatory authorities and financial institutions to maintain the sector’s 
liquidity and stability during emergencies.   
5. Debt sustainability  Nepal’s public debt remains lower than other low-income countries and a net external 
creditor. ADB’s debt sustainability assessment finds that from 30.1% of GDP in FY2019, 
the pandemic increases the debt-to-GDP ratio to 39.0% in FY2020 and 43.4% in 
FY2021 as growth dips and the primary balance worsens to fight the pandemic and 
support recovery. As growth picks up, public debt will continue to rise at a slower pace

II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Coronavirus disease and initial government response. The first case of COVID-19 
was identified in Nepal on 24 January 2020. Since then, the government initiated various 
containment  measures  including  procuring  essential  supplies,  equipment,  and  medicine; 
upgrading health infrastructure; training medical personnel; and spreading public awareness. 
Other measures included prohibiting promotional activities or events, canceling on-arrival visas, 
suspending the issuance of migrant workers’ work permits, suspending school classes and 
examinations, canceling all international flights, and postponing the National Assembly. On 
24 March 2020, a nationwide lockdown came into effect. 
 
4.  On  8 May  2020,  Nepal  had  107 confirmed  cases,  with  no  deaths  recorded. It  has 
conducted about 15,492 swab tests and quarantined about 20,217 people. Although the number 
of confirmed cases is still small, Nepal is considered a high-risk country for rapid spread of 
COVID-19 infections because of its vulnerable public health system, underdeveloped sanitation 
and  other  infrastructure,  and  densely  populated  urban  and  semi-urban  areas.  Further,  a 
substantial number of Nepali migrant workers are returning from affected countries. As of 8 May 
2020, 20,217 migrant workers returned to Nepal. Without urgent and effective containment 
measures, Nepal’s risk of rapidly spreading the infection is high. As a landlocked country that is 
highly dependent on imports, Nepal also recognizes regional cooperation to be crucial in ensuring 
a coordinated response to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, and maintain open access and 
uninterrupted supply links. It has signed the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
(SAARC) COVID-19 response joint plan, which calls for countries in the region to work together 
to implement containment and surveillance measures. In addition, Nepal pledged $1 million to the 
SAARC COVID-19 Emergency Fund.

3 
5.  Government’s public health forecasts and health system status. In April 2020, under 
the framework of the National Relief Program, the government released the Health Sector 
Emergency Response Plan: COVID-19 Pandemic.3 The plan was further revised in May 2020. 
The plan’s objective is to prepare and strengthen the response of the health system to minimize 
the pandemic’s health impact. It presents four scenarios based on COVID-19 positive case load 
including: (i) a maximum number of positive cases under 2,000; (ii) a maximum number of positive 
cases between 2,000 and 5,000; (iii) a maximum number of positive cases between 5,000 and 
10,000; and (iv) a maximum number of positive cases greater than 10,000.4 Each of these levels 
further segregates cases into three levels of severity assuming that 80% of cases would need 
general treatment at the hospital with isolation ward and beds, 15% would need hospitalization 
with oxygen support and only 5% would need intensive care unit (ICU) services. The plan 
prescribes strategic approaches and key interventions for (i) health systems, (ii) public health and 
social measures, (iii) curative care interventions, and (iv) strengthened management for COVID-
19 response.5 To meet the plan’s requirements, Nepal’s health system requires significant 
upscaling and expansion, especially for the number of quarantine, isolation, hospital and ICU 
beds (Table 2).6 Additionally, Nepal has a lower polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing rate at 
0.56 per thousand population when compared to other neighboring countries such as India at 
1.10, Bhutan at 3.21, and Bangladesh at 0.71.7 Summary of cross country comparison of COVID-
19 related data is also included in Appendix 2.8

7.  Economic  impact  of the  pandemic.  The  pandemic  has  caused  serious  economic

8.  Finance sector impact. Nepal’s finance sector loans outstanding totaled NRs3,213 billion 
in March 2020, with exposure to hotels, restaurants, and other service industries totaling 8.61% 
of the portfolio. Loans to micro-, small-, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) totaled 10.85%.11 
The portfolio performance of loans to the service industries and MSMEs is expected to deteriorate 
due to the business disruptions caused by the pandemic. The banking nonperforming loan (NPL) 
ratio worsened from an NPL ratio of 1.74% in December 2019 to 1.77% in March 2020. Similarly, 
the finance sector’s capital adequacy ratio deteriorated from 14.19% in December 2019 to 13.97% 
in March 2020.12 The pandemic has also adversely affected the liquidity of the finance system, 
which  will  lead  to  limited  access  to  finance  for  the  private  sector,  in  particular  MSMEs. 
Remittances, which grew by 3.61% in FY2019, declined by 50.7% in April 2020 compared with 
April 2019—falling for the first time since the earthquake in 2015.13 
 
9.  Poverty, social, and gender impact. The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionate 
impacts  on  the  poor,  informal  sector  workers,  migrant  workers,  households  depending  on 
remittances, and women. With the economic disruption caused by the pandemic, vulnerable 
individuals, including those who are just above the poverty line, are likely to be pushed below the 
poverty line. Also, Nepal’s estimated poverty headcount ratios are 3.9% at $1.90 a day, 27.6% at 
$3.20 a day, and 65.1% at $5.50 a day for FY2020.14 The adverse impacts of the pandemic are

10.  Nepal’s poverty is partly related to the large segment of the population who are employed 
in the informal sector. Informal sector employment accounts for 84.6% of total employment.15 
Informal sector workers are not entitled to sick pay or health insurance, and are ineligible for social 
security benefits. Women are likely to be most affected, as they comprise 66.5% of informal sector 
workers in Nepal, and the lockdown has increased their household and care work. Returnee 
migrant workers are anticipated to remain unemployed because of the pandemic’s adverse impact 
on the domestic economy and employment market. Migrant workers comprise about 12% women 
and several historically disadvantaged groups—the Adivasi Janajati (indigenous groups), Hill 
Dalits (lowest caste), other Madheshi (inhabitants of the Terai) castes, Terai Janajatis, and 
Madheshi Dalits.16 The decline in remittances, which is a critical source of income for many Nepali 
households, exacerbated by unpaid care work, reinforces the burden on women as the primary 
family caregiver. Moreover, the imposition of home quarantine poses a higher risk of violence 
against women and inhibits timely interventions to gender-based violence. Since women comprise 
70% of public sector health workers including frontline personnel, they face an unprecedented 
workload in overstretched health facilities. In addition, 51,420 female community health volunteers 
who support basic health services for the government’s National Relief Program, forming an 
integral part of the health care system, are at increased risk of infection.17  
 
11.  Government’s  countercyclical  expenditure  program.  The  government’s 
countercyclical development expenditure program is estimated to cost about $1.26 billion for 
FY2020: (i) $347 million for health and medical support, (ii) $359 million for social protection for 
the poor and vulnerable, and (iii) $555 million for economic support for affected sectors. The 
program’s key objective is to control the pandemic and mitigate the pandemic’s adverse impacts 
on livelihood and employment, especially for the poor and vulnerable including women. The 
program’s health and medical support key areas include (i) building additional quarantine and 
hospital bed capacity, (ii) scaling up critical care bed capacity, (iii) introducing health insurance 
scheme for medical personnel, and (iv) providing additional financial incentives to medical and

24.  Debt sustainability. Nepal’s public debt remains lower than other low-income countries 
and a net external creditor. Under the ADB baseline, the public debt to GDP ratio is projected to 
increase over the projection period but will remain below 50% by FY2025. ADB’s assessment 
finds that from 30.1% of GDP in FY2019, the pandemic increases the debt-to-GDP ratio to 39.0% 
in FY2020 and 43.4% in FY2021 as growth dips and the primary balance worsens to fight the 
pandemic and support recovery. The projected debt path is slightly higher (1 percentage point) 
than the baseline considered under the IMF’s Rapid Credit Facility (RCF) approved on 6 May 
2020, primarily due to a higher primary deficit assumption in FY2020. For instance, in FY2020 
alone, the increase in the public debt GDP ratio of 8.9% of GDP is mainly due to the high primary 
deficit of 7.9%. Nepal’s public-debt to GDP ratio will stabilize when the primary deficit is at 3.5% 
of GDP. Further, while the IMF baseline includes COVID-19 response from key development 
partners namely ADB (proposed $250 million), IMF ($214 million already approved), and the 
World Bank ($29 million approved in FY2020), ADB’s baseline includes additional support from 
World Bank ($250 million likely to be effective in FY2021) and AIIB ($100 million proposed in 
FY2021). These multilateral loans are about 1.6% of GDP in FY2020 and 1% in FY2021.  
 
25.   Risks to Nepal’s debt sustainability remain contained. Main risks include low growth and 
high primary deficits. A slowing Indian economy and sluggish remittances are likely to slow 
Nepal’s growth. A negative growth shock, with GDP growth 1.1 percentage points below the 
baseline in the first two years along with corresponding falls in nominal growth, is likely to increase 
the debt-to-GDP ratio at a faster pace reaching a peak of 49.3% in FY2025. A primary balance

to a bumper harvest, and continued improvement in electricity 
supply.  Remittance  income  has  helped  maintain 
macroeconomic stability by (i) supporting the external current 
account,  (ii)  increasing  tax  revenue  through  induced 
consumption and imports, and (iii) increasing income of poor 
households. Inflation has begun to rise following a decline from 
a recent peak of 9.9% in FY2016. More recently, inflation 
became 6.5% in the first 8 months of FY2020.  
 
Fiscal deficit moderated to 5.1% of GDP in FY2019, after rising 
to  6.6%  in  FY2018,  on  lower  than  planned  capital 
expenditures.  Current account deficit narrowed from 8.2% of 
GDP in FY2018 to 7.7% of GDP in FY2019. Gross foreign 
exchange reserves were comfortable at $9.5 billion, enough to 
cover  import  of  7.8 months  in  FY2019.   With an  average 
revenue  to  GDP  of  23.8%  from  FY2017  to  FY2019, 
the revenue mobilization (excluding foreign grants) has been 
robust.  Total external debt stood at 17.0% of GDP in FY2019, 
slightly lower than 17.3% of GDP in FY2018. External debt is 
largely  long-term  at  concessional  rates  from  multilateral 
financial institutions and bilateral donors. External debt service 
is equivalent to about 8.2% of exports of goods and non-factor 
services. 
 
IMF Article IV consultation concluded in February 2020, which 
did  not  take  the  COVID-19  impact  into  consideration, 
confirmed that Nepal had seen strong growth and significant 
poverty reduction, and had expected Nepal to growth 6.0% in 
FY2020. IMF further assessed that a neutral fiscal stance 
driven by under spending of the budget is expected to help 
contain external and domestic pressures.e A neutral fiscal 
stance driven by under spending of the budget is expected to 
help contain external and domestic pressures. 
 
4.  Structural reforms   As part of the pandemic response, the government-initiated 
policy,  and  institutional  structural  reforms  to  enhance  the 
public  sector  resilience  to  emergencies,  especially  in  the 
health sector. MOHP developed the Health Sector Emergency 
Response Plan: COVID-19 Pandemic, which provides detailed 
institutional mechanisms and procedures to be adopted during 
a pandemic. The plan provides detailed steps on (i) command 
and  control,  (ii)  risk  assessment,  (iii)  communication,  (iv) 
surveillance,  (v)  case  investigation  and  treatment,  (vi)

28  Appendix 4 
  Asian Development Bank Assessment 
 
preventing  spread  of  the  disease  in  the  community,  (vii) 
maintaining  essential  services,  and  (viii)  research  and 
evaluation. The plan prescribes strategic approaches and key 
interventions for (i) health systems, (ii) public health and social 
measures, (iii) curative care, and (iv) strengthened monitoring. 
The  management  and  oversight  functions  are  further 
elaborated into (i) safety and security of frontline staff, (ii) 
human  resource  management  and  capacity  building,  (iii) 
logistics and supply chain management, (iv) collaboration and 
partnership, and (v) monitoring, evaluation and reporting.  
 
In  the  pandemic  response  plan,  the  government  also 
incorporated financial sector structural reforms to enable the 
regulatory authorities and financial institutions to maintain the 
sector’s liquidity and stability at the time of emergencies. NRB, 
the central bank included the reform measures of (i) allowing 
banks count loans to health facilities for COVID-19 treatment 
qualify towards priority sector lending requirements, and (ii) 
lowering the mandatory cash reserve rate from 4% to 3% and 
reduce the interest rate on the standing liquidity facility rate 
from 6% to 5%. Further, the government expanded its scope 
of  the  Prime  Minister’s  Employment  Program,  which  was 
originally  targeted  at  domestic  unemployment  to  returnee 
migrant workers whose contracts in their host countries abroad 
were affected due to the pandemic.  
 
5.  Debt sustainability  ADB’s debt sustainability assessment finds that from 30.1% of 
GDP in FY2019, the pandemic increases the debt-to-GDP 
ratio to 39.0% in FY2020 and 43.4% in FY2021 as growth dips 
and the primary balance worsens to fight the pandemic and 
support  recovery.  This  assessment  assumes  the  primary 
deficit to be 7.9% of GDP in FY2020. As growth picks up, 
public debt will continue to rise at a slower pace and reach 
48.5% in FY2025. The debt path of the ADB baseline is about 
1 percentage point higher than that projected by IMF in the 
RCF  report,  largely  due  to  the  higher  primary  deficit  in 
FY2020.a Nepal’s public-debt to GDP ratio will stabilize when 
the primary deficit is at 3.5% of GDP. In a stress test scenario 
of  a  negative  growth  shock,  with  GDP  growth  one-half 
standard deviation (1.1 percentage points) below the baseline 
in the first two years along with corresponding falls in nominal 
growth, is likely to increase debt to GDP at a faster pace 
reaching  a  peak  of  49.3%  in  FY2025.  A  primary  balance 
shock, where the primary deficit as a percent of GDP is one 
half  standard  deviation  (1.4  percentage  points)  above  the 
baseline in the first two years of projection, will elevate debt 
levels to just cross the 50% threshold to 50.5% in FY2025. The 
two shocks combined will push the debt-to-GDP ratio further 
higher, crossing the 50% threshold earlier in FY2024 and 
reaching 51.3% in FY2025.

Appendix 4  29 
  Asian Development Bank Assessment 
 
Approved  and  proposed  COVID-19  response  assistances 
from international financial institutions are $843 million in this 
and next fiscal year. These borrowings are used to finance the 
estimated fiscal deficit in FY2020 and FY2021 and hence are 
already reflected in the baseline debt path. The emergency 
assistance includes from ADB (proposed $250 million), IMF 
($214 million already approved), the World Bank ($29 million 
approved in FY2020 and $250 million likely to be effective in 
FY2021) and AIIB ($100 million proposed in FY2021). These 
multilateral loans are about 1.6% of GDP in FY2020 and 1% 
in FY2021.  
  
The 2020 IMF Article IV reports that Nepal has a strong debt 
carrying  capacity.  A  composite  indicator  using  real  GDP 
growth, remittances, foreign exchange reserves and world 
growth shows a composite indicator score of 3.28 which is in 
the range of a strong rating. Nepal continues to meet its debt-
servicing  obligations.  The  thresholds  for  external-debt  to 
revenue and external-debt to exports used in Article IV are 
21% and 23%, respectively. Between 2009 and 2019, the 
average external-debt to revenue and external-debt to exports 
were 5% and 10%, respectively. The IMF’s latest staff report 
for the disbursement under RCF approved on 6 May 2020 
confirmed that even under the COVID-19 pandemic, Nepal’s 
debt is assessed to remain at a low risk of external and overall 
debt distress, unchanged from the 2020 Article IV report. 
 
6.  Coordination with the IMF  ADB regularly holds consultation with IMF as part of Article IV 
consultations, processing of PBLs, and other missions. The 
latest Article IV consultation was held in-country during 5-
17January  2020.  The  government  has  requested  IMF  to 
extend the Rapid Credit Facility (SDR156.9 million, about $214 
million)  to  respond  to  the  COVID-19  pandemic.  An 
assessment letter from the IMF has been secured confirming 
the  soundness  of  the  government’s  macroeconomic 
management and other policies. ADB regularly participates in 
dialogue with the World Bank, IMF, and other development 
partners on reform initiatives to support macroeconomic and 
financial  stability  in  the  country.  Further,  ADB  is  closely 
interacting  with  IMF  on  the  CARES  Program  to  ensure 
complementarity with IMF’s COVID-19 support for Nepal.f
